title: 112_hr1269
content:
The Act may be cited as the "National Women's History Museum Act of 2011". Definitions are provided in the Act. The Act, known as the "National Women's History Museum Act of 2011," defines key terms such as Administrator, CERCLA, Committees, Museum, and Property. The Property, located in the District of Columbia, consists of Squares 325 and 326 bounded by 12th Street, Independence Avenue, C Street, and the James Forrestal Building in Southwest Washington. It includes air rights, improvements, and appurtenances. SEC. 3. CONVEYANCE OF PROPERTY. The Administrator will convey the Property to the Museum with terms and conditions to protect US interests and further the Act's purposes. An agreement must be reached within 180 days, addressing mitigation of impacts, security concerns, and operational protocols. The Administrator will convey the Property to the Museum at its fair market value determined by an independent appraisal. The appraisal terms and conditions must be mutually agreed upon by both parties. The Property will be conveyed to the Museum at fair market value determined by an independent appraisal. The appraisal must assume no hazardous substances are present, and the purchase price will be paid into the Federal Buildings Fund. The proceeds can be used for any lawful purpose, and the Property will be dedicated for use as a national women's history museum for a 99-year period. The Property will be conveyed to the Museum at fair market value for use as a national women's history museum for a 99-year period. No Federal funds can be used for the purchase or construction on the Property. If the Property is not used as a museum or construction doesn't start within 5 years, it will revert to the United States. The museum facility on the Property must be operational within 5 years, or it will revert to the United States under the custody of the Administrator. The conveyance must occur within 3 years of the enactment of the Act, with possible extensions for the Museum to fulfill its obligations. SEC. 4. ENVIRONMENTAL MATTERS.

The Administrator can contract with the Museum for environmental response actions on the Property, with costs credited to the purchase price. Compliance with environmental laws is not affected by this Act.

SEC. 5. INCIDENTAL COSTS. SEC. 5. INCIDENTAL COSTS. The Museum will cover all expenses related to complying with this Act, including studies, surveys, relocating tenants, and mitigating impacts on Federal buildings. Existing Authorities are not limited by this Act, including the National Capital Planning Commission and the Commission of Fine Arts. The Administrator must cooperate with the Museum on zoning and land use matters related to the Property's development. Cooperation does not require the Administrator to incur costs, and consent is contingent on the Property being developed in accordance with the Act. The Museum must submit annual reports to the Administrator and Committees detailing development and construction activities for 5 years after the Property conveyance or museum facility completion.
